segment.source: System cryptography Force strong key protection for user keys stored on the computer (Windows 10)
segment.target: System cryptography Force strong key protection for user keys stored on the computer (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System cryptography Force strong key protection for user keys stored on the computer security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System cryptography Force strong key protection for user keys stored on the computer security policy setting.

segment.source: System cryptography: Force strong key protection for user keys stored on the computer
segment.target: System cryptography: Force strong key protection for user keys stored on the computer

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System cryptography: Force strong key protection for user keys stored on the computer security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System cryptography: Force strong key protection for user keys stored on the computer security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines whether users can use private keys, such as their Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (S/MIME) key, without a password.
segment.target: This policy setting determines whether users can use private keys, such as their Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (S/MIME) key, without a password.

segment.source: Configuring this policy setting so that users must provide a password every time they use a key (in addition to their domain password) makes it more difficult for a malicious user to access locally-stored user keys, even if the attacker takes control of the user's device and determines their logon password.
segment.target: Configuring this policy setting so that users must provide a password every time they use a key (in addition to their domain password) makes it more difficult for a malicious user to access locally-stored user keys, even if the attacker takes control of the user's device and determines their logon password.

segment.source: User input is not required when new keys are stored and used
segment.target: User input is not required when new keys are stored and used

segment.source: User is prompted when the key is first used
segment.target: User is prompted when the key is first used

segment.source: User must enter a password each time they use a key
segment.target: User must enter a password each time they use a key

segment.source: Set this policy to User must enter a password each time they use a key.
segment.target: Set this policy to User must enter a password each time they use a key.

segment.source: Users must enter their password every time they access a key that is stored on their computer.
segment.target: Users must enter their password every time they access a key that is stored on their computer.

segment.source: For example, if users use an S/MIME certificate to digitally sign their email, they will be forced to enter the password for that certificate every time they send a signed email message.
segment.target: For example, if users use an S/MIME certificate to digitally sign their email, they will be forced to enter the password for that certificate every time they send a signed email message.

segment.source: For some organizations, the overhead that is caused by using this value might be too high, but they should set the value at a minimum to User is prompted when the key is first used.
segment.target: For some organizations, the overhead that is caused by using this value might be too high, but they should set the value at a minimum to User is prompted when the key is first used.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: If a user's account is compromised or the user's device is inadvertently left unsecured, the malicious user can use the keys that are stored for the user to access protected resources.
segment.target: If a user's account is compromised or the user's device is inadvertently left unsecured, the malicious user can use the keys that are stored for the user to access protected resources.

segment.source: Configure the System cryptography: Force strong key protection for user keys stored on the computer setting to User must enter a password each time they use a key so that users must provide a password that is distinct from their domain password every time they use a key.
segment.target: Configure the System cryptography: Force strong key protection for user keys stored on the computer setting to User must enter a password each time they use a key so that users must provide a password that is distinct from their domain password every time they use a key.

segment.source: This configuration makes it more difficult for an attacker to access locally stored user keys, even if the attacker takes control of the user's computer and determines the logon password.
segment.target: This configuration makes it more difficult for an attacker to access locally stored user keys, even if the attacker takes control of the user's computer and determines the logon password.

segment.source: Users must type their password every time they access a key that is stored on their device.
segment.target: Users must type their password every time they access a key that is stored on their device.

segment.source: For example, if users use an S/MIME certificate to digitally sign their email, they are forced to type the password for that certificate every time they send a signed email message.
segment.target: For example, if users use an S/MIME certificate to digitally sign their email, they are forced to type the password for that certificate every time they send a signed email message.

segment.source: For some organizations, the overhead that is involved by using this configuration may be too high.
segment.target: For some organizations, the overhead that is involved by using this configuration may be too high.

segment.source: At a minimum, this setting should be set to User is prompted when the key is first used.
segment.target: At a minimum, this setting should be set to User is prompted when the key is first used.
